items.title: Why the ‘iPhone of smartwatches’ remains so elusive
items.summary:
- The quest for a smartwatch that matches the transformative impact of the iPhone continues, but no product has yet achieved that status.
- Apple Watch is a success but not a game-changer; other companies have attempted to innovate in this space without success, such as Human’s AI Pin.
- Recent developments suggest Apple is exploring camera integration for future Apple Watch models to enhance features like “Visual Intelligence.”
- The European Commission has mandated Apple improve iOS compatibility with third-party smartwatches, which could influence future innovations in the market.
- Industry veterans, like Eric Migicovsky, cite restrictions imposed by Apple as hindering the smartwatch industry, underscoring the need for more interoperability.

items.title: ChatGPT may be making us lonelier
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- Studies from MIT Media Lab and OpenAI reveal a correlation between heavy ChatGPT use and increased loneliness.
- Heavy users often consider the chatbot as a 'friend' and attribute human-like emotions to it.
- The studies suggest that loneliness may lead individuals to seek emotional support from AI, rather than AI causing loneliness directly.
- Analysis shows higher usage of ChatGPT correlates with dependence, problematic use, and lower social interaction.
- ChatGPT has over 400 million users globally, with many using it for personal conversations despite concerns from mental health professionals.

items.title: Dating is even more partisan in the Trump era
items.summary:
- Americans are dating across party lines less, with 71% of Democrats unwilling to date a Trump voter as of 2020.
- Niche dating apps are emerging for political alignment; right-wing apps, particularly Date Right Stuff, are gaining traction.
- The MAGA movement is successfully developing dating platforms, while liberal-only apps struggle, often being viewed as reactions to opposition.
- Date Right Stuff was co-founded by John McEntee and received significant funding from Peter Thiel, despite initial controversies and slow downloads at launch.

items.title: ‘Setting boundaries with your partner. That’s what’s up!’: This TikTok account is teaching Gen Z men all about positive masculinity
These 5 new AI tools can help you do everything from managing tasks to improving your public speaking
Nvidia-backed CoreWeave slashes IPO size and price amid investor concerns
items.summary:
- CoreWeave plans to reduce its IPO size and lower share price amid investor concerns.
- Now aiming to sell 37.5 million shares at $40 each, down 23.5% from initial plans.
- Nvidia will anchor the IPO with a $250 million order, raising about $1.5 billion and valuing CoreWeave at $23 billion.
- The roadshow received a weaker reception as investors are wary due to concerns about long-term growth and financial risks related to its reliance on Microsoft and a capital-intensive business model.

items.title: Why Tesla may be spared from Trump’s auto tariffs
items.summary:
- Tesla is less affected by Trump’s potential auto tariffs due to its largely domestic production and strong financial performance.
- Tesla shares have recently increased by about 2%, despite a larger 40% decline since mid-December due to global protests against the company.
- The auto tariffs, which could reach 25%, are expected to disrupt the automotive industry, affecting other major companies like Ford and GM, whose shares have dropped significantly.
- Tesla is expected to report approximately 398,000 vehicle deliveries for the first quarter soon.

items.title: Elon Musk privately pressured Reddit CEO Steve Huffman on content moderation: report
items.summary:
- Elon Musk messaged Reddit CEO Steve Huffman while pressuring the platform on content moderation.
- Musk criticized Reddit subreddits for blocking links to X in protest of his actions.
- Following discussions with Musk, Reddit enacted a 72-hour ban on the subreddit r/WhitePeopleTwitter due to violent content.
- Musk has rolled back content moderation policies on X and has faced criticism for his approach to moderation and user behavior.

items.title: The slim phone era is (finally) back
items.author: Sam Byford
items.summary:
- Major phone manufacturers are returning to prioritizing thinness in smartphone design.
- Samsung announced the Galaxy S25 Edge, a slimline smartphone in its new lineup.
- Apple is reportedly planning a thinner 2025 iPhone with a single camera.
- The trend of thin phones mirrors past cycles in fashion and design.
- Historically, companies have boasted about the thinness of their devices, but the trend shifted to thicker models for durability.

items.title: An AI pioneer is launching a blockchain-powered marketplace for open-source models and applications
items.author: Illia Polosukhin
items.summary:
- Illia Polosukhin, co-inventor of the Transformer architecture, is launching a company called [Near AI](https://near.ai/).
- Near AI offers a blockchain-powered marketplace aimed at hosting and distributing open-source AI models, enhancing data privacy for users and developers.
- The platform protects developers from compliance burdens associated with user data management while allowing them to monetize their models through token payments.
- The Near platform aims to create a decentralized network of verified users who can locally run models securely.
- Near Foundation raised $650 million between 2018 and 2022 to support the Near protocol, with Near AI expected to raise more funds in the future.

items.title: State Department announces approval of armed drones sale to Qatar for nearly $2 billion
The ‘New York Times’’s copyright lawsuit against OpenAI can proceed, says a federal judge
What’s an email mask? Here’s why tech experts say you should be using one
items.summary:
- Email masking provides a temporary email address to protect your actual email during online activities.
- Services like DuckDuckGo, Firefox Relay, and Apple’s Hide My Email offer email masking features to enhance privacy.
- Users can control their email sharing and prevent spam by using temporary addresses.
- It's important to choose reputable providers that maintain user privacy and security.
- Email masks are useful when the ownership of a service could expose sensitive information or when unsure how a website might use your email.

items.title: For Gen Z, viral videos are the new primetime
items.summary:
- Gen Z prefers social media content over traditional TV and movies, according to Deloitte's Digital Media Trends survey.
- 56% of Gen Z and 43% of millennials find social media content more relevant, feeling a stronger connection with creators than actors.
- The entertainment industry is competing for attention in an era of six hours of daily screen time, with tech platforms having an upper hand.
- Viral videos are seen as the new primetime, while creators build parasocial relationships with their audience.
- Some creators are transitioning to traditional media for better contracts and exposure, while celebrities are leveraging social media.
- Subscription fatigue is a concern, with many feeling they overpay for streaming services, necessitating traditional media adaptation to compete effectively.

items.title: The Apple Watch faces a wearables wake-up call
items.summary:
- Apple Watch sales have been declining for three consecutive years, from 43 million units sold in 2022 to 34 million expected in 2024.
- Market share decreased from 29.6% to 22.5% as competitors like Garmin and budget brands gained traction.
- Apple has struggled to introduce compelling new features, leading to a stagnation in innovation on the watch front.

items.title: AI is painful for journalists but healthy for journalism
Simon & Schuster wants to be your favorite content creator
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- Simon & Schuster will launch a web series called **Bookstore Blitz**, focusing on book promotions.
- Sean Manning, the new publisher, aims to transform the company into a media powerhouse.
- Plans include an awards-style interview program named **Read Carpet**.
- There is a growing demand for book-related content online, notably from TikTok, contributing to significant print book sales.
- Popular authors have seen viral success through platforms like TikTok, rivaling traditional advertising methods.
- Manning identifies social media as a major competitor for publishers.

items.title: Supreme Court upholds Biden’s ghost gun rule requiring serial numbers and background checks
Ex-officials criticize Trump team's use of Signal for sensitive discussions
items.summary:
- Current and former government technologists are shocked that Trump officials used Signal for war planning against Houthis.
- Participants included Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, Vice President JD Vance, and Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard.
- National Security Advisor Mike Waltz inadvertently invited Atlantic editor Jeffrey Goldberg to a sensitive conversation.
- Experts warn using nonsecure consumer apps for classified discussions is highly reckless and unprofessional.

items.title: U.S. blacklists these Chinese tech firms in latest update to export control list
items.author: Elaine Kurtenbach
items.summary:
- The U.S. added over 50 Chinese companies to its export control list, aimed at restricting military technology acquisition.
- Companies from Taiwan, Iran, Pakistan, South Africa, and the UAE were also included, totaling around 80 entities.
- China’s Foreign Ministry condemned the U.S. actions as violations of international law, saying it unjustly suppresses Chinese enterprises.
- The update targets entities like the Beijing Academy of Artificial Intelligence, claimed to develop AI for military purposes.
- The U.S. goals include preventing China's development of advanced weaponry and securing supply chains.

items.title: The ‘living globe’ that can help drones fly without GPS
items.author: Alex Pasternack
items.summary:
- Drones are learning to navigate using cameras and AI instead of GPS, especially when GPS is unreliable.
- Maxar introduced Raptor, which matches drone camera feeds with 3D Earth data for positioning.
- Raptor is advantageous for low-altitude and nighttime operations with infrared cameras, achieving accuracy of around three meters.
- Maxar’s 3D globe comprises 125 petabytes of data covering over 90 million square kilometers, with ongoing updates.

items.title: ‘Signalgate’ has turned a string of patriotic emoji into a meme that will live in infamy
items.summary:
- Signalgate is the latest scandal involving a group chat between Trump officials, generating numerous memes.
- The chat allegedly included discussions about military plans against Houthis in Yemen, confirmed by subsequent events.
- The National Security Council acknowledged the chat's authenticity but defended it as a symbol of policy coordination among officials.

items.title: Will AI-generated anime reshape storytelling—or replace it?
items.summary:
- AI is entering animation, enhancing production speed and reducing costs.
- Vidu AI partners with Aura Productions for a 50-episode AI-generated sci-fi anime series set for 2025.
- The series will be released on social media to adapt to changing viewer habits, promoting on-demand content consumption.

items.title: This watchdog is tracking how AI firms are quietly backing off their safety pledges
items.summary:
- A nonprofit, the Midas Project, tracks changes to AI companies' safety and ethical commitments as they alter policies under pressure.  
- Launched in 2024, their AI Safety Watchtower project monitors 16 companies, including OpenAI and Google.  
- The Trump administration's rollback of AI safety regulations raises concerns about the abandonment of safety commitments.

items.title: TikTok is facing a rare meme drought. Inside the Great Meme Depression of 2025
items.summary:
- A meme shortage has been observed on TikTok, dubbed the "Great Meme Depression of 2025".
- The meme drought was first mentioned on March 10, 2025, by user @goofangel, who noted a lack of original memes.
- The term "Great Meme Depression" has become a meme itself, leading to meta-commentary and nostalgic discussions on TikTok.
- The fast-paced trend cycle may be unable to keep up with demand, leading to a recycling of stale content.

items.title: ‘We Thank You, Elon Musk’: Superfan Alessandra Basher’s music video has divided the internet
items.author: null
items.summary:
- Alessandra Basher, a superfan of Elon Musk, released a music video filmed on a Tesla Cybertruck.
- The video, posted on X, garnered mixed reactions, with some seeing it as satire and others as genuine praise for Musk.
- Lyrics include references to SpaceX, Tesla, and Musk's impact, sparking debate on social media about its sincerity.
- Basher faced backlash from critics but clarified her intent was to create a fun tribute to Musk's contributions.

items.title: OpenAI brings AI image generation directly to ChatGPT
items.author: Sam Altman
items.summary:
- OpenAI introduces image generation feature in ChatGPT, powered by GPT-4o model.
- Initially available to ChatGPT Plus, Pro, Team, and free users, with Enterprise and Education tiers to follow.
- Users can create or modify images based on prompts, conversations, and uploaded files; enhanced understanding of image context.
- Functionality includes refining images using natural language to maintain visual consistency.
- Aimed at creating work-related visuals requiring precision and user-contextual images.

items.title: NPR CEO Katherine Maher makes the case for why public radio is essential to American democracy
items.summary:
- NPR CEO Katherine Maher is set to testify before the DOGE congressional subcommittee about the importance of federal funding for public radio.
- Maher emphasizes that cuts to funding would negatively impact Americans' access to vital news, particularly in rural areas.
- NPR aims to reengage with audiences and frame its identity as an inclusive media outlet serving all Americans.
- She notes that while NPR provides about 25% of public radio content, local stations play crucial roles in community engagement and programming.
- Maher addresses concerns about perceived bias in NPR reporting and underscores the organization's commitment to serving diverse audiences.
- The potential loss of $121.5 million in federal funding could significantly affect local stations, especially those in less affluent and rural areas.

items.title: German startup Isar Aerospace cancels maiden voyage of orbital rocket
items.summary:
- Isar Aerospace canceled the test flight of its Spectrum rocket due to unfavorable winds in Norway.
- The launch was expected from Andøya island; the company may reschedule later in the week.
- The Spectrum rocket is designed for small and medium-size satellites, measuring 28 meters (91 feet).
- The company considers a 30-second flight as a success for its first test and aims to collect data and experience.
- Isar Aerospace has raised over 400 million euros ($435 million) and plans to produce 40 rockets annually near Munich.

items.title: The Trump administration’s Signal scandal shows humans will always be the weakest link in cybersecurity
items.summary:
- A journalist from The Atlantic had unrestricted access to a private Signal group chat involving high-level government officials, discussing imminent military actions.
- The incident is deemed the worst U.S. security breach in a generation, attributed to human error by misidentifying the journalist as a government official.
- Experts underline that while encryption apps like Signal are secure, the real vulnerability lies with the users, emphasizing the necessity of operational security.

items.title: Tesla sold 42.6% less cars in Europe this year. Here’s why
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Tesla's sales in Europe decreased by 42.6% in 2024, according to ACEA data.
- The company's market share fell to 1.8% of total market and 10.3% of BEV market in February 2024, down from 2.8% and 21.6% in the previous year.
- Tesla sold fewer than 17,000 cars in Europe compared to over 28,000 in the same month last year.
- Factors contributing to the decline include increased competition, economic slowdown, and an aging vehicle lineup.
- The impending launch of Tesla's Model Y midsize SUV may influence future sales performance.

items.title: Otter’s new AI agents are built to boost sales and streamline meetings
items.summary:
- Otter introduces a new AI agent for real-time interaction during meetings, capable of answering questions and managing tasks like scheduling follow-ups.
- The agent can draw information from previous meetings and external company resources, ensuring confidentiality during responses.
- Currently activated with a trigger phrase, future versions may respond proactively to questions, similar to human participants.
- The AI supports Zoom, with plans for integration with Microsoft Teams and Google Meet.
- Otter has achieved $100 million in annual recurring revenue and is also releasing other AI agents like Sales Agent for sales teams and SDR Agent for live demos.
- The SDR Agent is already live on Otter’s website and can be customized for customers to demonstrate their products.

items.title: Samsung CEO Han Jong-Hee, head of consumer electronics, dies at 63
items.summary:
- Han Jong-Hee, a senior Samsung Electronics executive, died at age 63 after a heart attack.
- Han was co-chief executive overseeing consumer electronics and mobile devices.
- He joined Samsung in 1988 and became co-vice chairman and CEO in 2022.
- Jun Young Hyun, the semiconductor chief executive, will assume Han's responsibilities as the sole CEO.

items.title: California lawmakers take on ‘surveillance pricing’ as FTC retreats
items.summary:
- Consumers often pay varying prices based on their personal data analyzed by algorithms, a practice termed 'surveillance pricing'.
- The practice has drawn criticism and was a focus of the FTC under former Chair Lina Khan, which released a study indicating AI tools help retailers increase revenue by as much as 5%.
- The current FTC under Chair Andrew Ferguson appears to be retreating from addressing surveillance pricing, having shut down public comment periods and dismissed pro-reform commissioners.

items.title: Waymo is expanding its robotaxi service to D.C. next year
items.author: Tekedra Mawakana, Dmitri Dolgov
items.summary:
- Waymo plans to expand its ride-hailing service, Waymo One, to Washington, D.C. in 2026.
- The city currently prohibits fully autonomous operations; Waymo will collaborate with local policymakers to formalize regulations.
- This is the first expansion into a city with regular snowfall; service will pause during snow or icy conditions until winter capabilities are added.
- Waymo has achieved full commercial deployment in San Francisco, Phoenix, and Los Angeles with over 4 million rides in 2024.
- Waymo vehicles have briefly tested in D.C. as part of cross-country testing, with more equipped vehicles arriving soon.

items.title: ‘I can’t stop’: Diners are stealing from restaurants—and posting about it on TikTok
These genetically engineered houseplants are 30 times better at clearing toxins
items.author: Patrick Torbey, Lionel Mora
items.summary:
- Neoplants, a startup co-founded by Patrick Torbey and Lionel Mora, introduced Power Drops, which enhance the air-cleaning ability of houseplants by 30 times.
- Power Drops consist of genetically modified soil bacteria that metabolize volatile organic compounds (VOCs), improving indoor air quality.
- The technology promises a 30% reduction in airborne toxins in a 160-square-foot room and will aid recovery efforts from recent wildfires in Los Angeles by absorbing lingering VOCs from homes.

items.title: Fintech Startup Alchemy Launches $100 Million Fund to Pay Influencers Faster
items.author: Isaac Wagschal
items.summary:
- Influencer marketing is a $10 billion industry, but inconsistent cash flow is a significant issue for many creators.
- Alchemy, a fintech startup, has launched a $100 million fund to provide upfront payments to creators based on projected earnings.
- The company uses a creator's past six months of earnings to project future income, allowing for lump-sum payments without loans or fixed repayment schedules.
- Alchemy partners with agencies and platforms to integrate its tools into brand deal workflows, aiming to normalize upfront payments in the industry.

items.title: How to cautiously use health advice from social media
items.summary:
- Influencers promote various health treatments and products, often lacking solid evidence.
- Caution is advised as many influencers may benefit financially from product promotions.
- A significant amount of health-related content on social media is misleading or promotes questionable medical practices.
- Checking the credentials of health influencers is crucial to ensure advice is reliable.
- Comparing influencer claims with prevailing medical consensus and reputable sources is recommended.

items.title: Section 230 faces bipartisan repeal effort. Experts say it’s a risky bet
items.summary:
- Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act protects tech platforms from legal liability for user-generated content.
- A bipartisan group, including Senators Lindsey Graham and Dick Durbin, is drafting a bill to repeal Section 230.
- Critics argue Section 230 allows Big Tech to evade accountability and contributes to online harm.
- Experts caution that repealing Section 230 without a replacement plan could lead to negative consequences for the tech industry.

items.title: TikTok has a big ADHD problem
Flexport CEO Ryan Petersen on what business leaders need to know about Trump’s tariffs
How ‘The Matrix’ helped build—and break—beleaguered production company Village Roadhouse
Would you pay $4,000 to solve your streaming movie problems?
items.summary:
- Kaleidescape offers a high-end streaming solution for home theaters with the Strato V Movie Player priced at $4,000.
- The product aims to provide cinema-quality viewing experiences and is designed for videophiles.
- CEO Tayloe Stansbury emphasizes the importance of presenting films as close to the director's intent as possible.
- Kaleidescape is trying to reach a broader audience after years of charging over $10,000 for its equipment.

items.title: These tech companies are building healthier social media habits for kids
items.summary:
- Global concerns about social media's negative impact on children's well-being are increasing.
- Australia prohibited children under 16 from using social media.
- Former U.S. Surgeon General called for warning labels on social media similar to tobacco warnings.
- Companies like Yoto, Life360, and Yondr are promoting healthier social media engagement for kids.
- Yoto's product allows kids to listen to audio content without screens, fostering independence.
- Life360 assists families in monitoring children while encouraging offline activities.
- Yondr creates pouches to limit phone use in educational settings, promoting safe digital habits.

items.title: This wellness app is like TikTok for your feelings
items.summary:
- Exist is a new iOS social wellness app aiming to transform journaling into a social experience.
- It unexpectedly gained popularity among middle-aged users, with an average sign-up age of 40.
- The app offers a community-focused approach to mental health, comparing itself to TikTok for sharing feelings and journaling publicly.
- Users can track moods, engage in community interactions, and utilize an AI-powered question feature for deeper reflection.
- A subscription service for guided audios and meditations is available for $5.99/month.

items.title: Suffering from loneliness? These businesses may have a cure
items.summary:
- Loneliness is a public health crisis, as dangerous to health as smoking up to 15 cigarettes a day.
- Social isolation increases risks for heart disease, strokes by 30%, and dementia by 50%.
- Companies are developing solutions to combat loneliness, encouraging offline connections through social apps and community events.
- Andy Dunn created 'Pie', a social app that uses AI to connect people with shared interests to combat social isolation.

items.title: Yes, Apple is delaying some AI features. But does it really matter?
items.summary:
- Apple announced the delay of some planned AI features for Siri to an unspecified later date.
- Critics in the tech press argue this could negatively affect iPhone sales, but the article contends this belief overestimates AI's appeal.
- Delayed features include Siri's personalized query understanding and in-app actions.
- The announcement was made to tech blogger John Gruber, which led to significant reactions in the media, including criticism about showcasing unfinished features as working prototypes.
- The article questions whether the delay will seriously impact iPhone sales, citing a lack of justification for such concerns.

items.title: Anthropic is adding web search to its Claude chatbot in a very smart way
items.summary:
- Anthropic has added web search capability to its Claude chatbot, a notable enhancement in AI.
- The feature is a 'feature preview' for U.S. users of the Claude 3.7 Sonnet model, with plans for broader rollout.
- Claude automatically decides if a web search would enhance its answer, differing from OpenAI's ChatGPT which requires manual selection for web searches.

items.title: In this horror game, the monster can see you through your webcam
items.summary:
- The horror game, *Eyes Never Wake*, uses a webcam to track players' movements in real time.
- Players must physically hide and stay silent to avoid being caught by an AI-driven monster.
- Available for wishlisting on Steam, the game has become viral, with a post on X gaining over 5.4 million views.
- Developers have stated that covering the webcam will inhibit movement, and no data is uploaded or stored during gameplay.
- No confirmed release date, but it is expected to launch soon on [Steam](https://store.steampowered.com/app/2526200/Eyes_Never_Wake/).
